div.p: The life and death of the rich man and Lazarus, Anothomized by way of Meditation.
With the Rich mans Funerall Sermon.
By George Phillips.
LONDON, Printed for Edward White, and are to be solde at his shop neere vnto the little North doore of Paules at the signe of the Gun. 1600.

div.head: The life and death of the Rich man and Lazarus.

q.hi: There was a certaine Rich man that was cloathed in Purple, and fine White, Luke. 16.19. and fared deliciously euery day. And there was a certaine begger, named Lazarus; that lay at his gate full of sores, desiring to be refreshed with the crumes that fell from his boord, but no man gaue them vnto him: but the dogges came and licked his sores. And it fortuned that the begger dyed, and was carried by the Angels into Abrahams bosome, The Rich man also dyed and was buried, and being in hell torments, &c.

div.head: Text.

q.hi: There was a certaine Rich man.

div.p:
THe Heathen wisserdes (whose knowledge of the true God, Mark. • . •• . being as imperfect as that mans sight, which saw men
walke like trees) said that the possessions of this life, are eyther the riches of the minde, or the goods of the body, or the benefits of fortune. But the spirit of truth binding these, and all other blessings together, Iam. 1.17. saith: that euery good and perfect gift commeth downe from the Father of lights: teaching vs to know both who is the right owner, and what is the true vse of them, which (as it should seeme by the sequell of this story) is not through ignoraunce obscured, but by negligence forgotten of the gripple penny-fathers of our golde-sicke age, who hauing hazarded their soules to that Lyon the Deuill for goods, Dan. 6.16. as Daniels body was indaungered to those Lyons for the honour of his God: the vulgar singling out some one of these: O say they; there is a very rich man. Mobile sic sequitur fortunae lumina vulgus. And in deed, of all such we may safelie say as this scripture doth: That they are rich, but with that difference of riches which the Apostle taught Timothy: 1. Tim. 6.17. namely with riches of this world. The vnsatiable hungring thereafter, the very Heathen haue mocked, and laughed to
scorne: with such like tauntes as this. O Ciues, Ciues querenda pecunia primum virtus post nummos. O Citizens get money first; let vertue come behinde.

And in truth who seeth not that they thinke themselues to haue vertue enough, if they possesse money enough? As vnseemely a thing: as when Hagar the Hand-mayde would bee aduaunced aboue Sara her Mistris. Gen. 16.4.

O foolish Galathians, Gal. 3.1. who hath bewitched you: said the Apostle, and O doting worldlings, how hath gaine inchaunted you? that your toyling heere, should bring you also a torment hereafter? The holy Ghost mentioning that shoure of wealth which was powered vpon Job, concludeth: Iob. 1.3. so that hee was one of the Principall men of the East Country. That wee might not consider onely how much hee had, but how well also he vsed that which he possessed. For no man is blessed because he hath much, but he hath much because he is blessed. And you may note this to bee true, by the testimony of God himselfe: who said that Iob feared God and eschewed euill, Iob. 1.8. two vertues rarely found in the
rich, but this is true both in rich and poore: that where no feare of GOD went before, there no auoyding of euill commeth after.

This is euident in them that couet to bee rich without exception, not regarding eyther from whome they get, or by what right they haue, so they haue. Who say to the wealth of this world, as Saint Paule said to the Corinthians. 1. Cor. 12.15 I will gladly spend, and bee spent for your sakes, who would clawe a muckhill to find a Pearle? who would rip their brothers intrayles for money, Iug. 14.8. as Sampson searched the Lyons carkasse for hony, whose whole endeuour is to serue their owne turne onely, Gen. 8.7. like Noas Crow: And haue euen solde themselues to do euill, not regarding that they haue done it in the sight of the Lord. 1. Kin. 2.20.

All that Iob hath be in thy hand, Iob. 1.12. said God to Sathan: O if some had so much power ouer their neighbors, how would they dominere ouer them? All that he hath is a large commission: yet this doe many take vpon them at this day, but by what authority? that is the question. Againe, Iob 2.6. vppon himselfe see thou laye not
thine hand, said God to the Deuill: then are not they worse then the Deuill, who not beeing content with all that a man hath in goods, do ceaze on his body too.

Be it knowne to you then: that a man in seeking to bee rich may sin greeuously, in these two Capitall pointes: First, in greedy snatching at what they see, like Achan and Ahab: Iosua. 7.21. 1. Kin. 21.2. Secondly in miserable keeping of that they possesse, as this rich wretch: And both appeare in all such as withhold that by wronge, which others should haue by right.

Therefore said the Lord, Luke. 12 15. beware of coueting: beware of it you rich men: for it will cause you to doe wronge, Pro. 28.21. if you may gaine but a peece of bread: beware of it you poore men, for as the wylde Asse is the Lyons pray in the wildernesse, Eccle. 12.20. so is the poore the pray of the rich. It was the saying of a man that had no lesse goodnes then goods: That gaine gotten with credit lost, is a badde bargaine.

It is no happinesse to plant your selues heere, and to floorish for a time, for so doe the very damned glister heere for a season, and yet they are no golde, but to
be as the Cedars which God hath planted, Psa. 112.3. is to be blessed: Riches and plenteousnes are in that house. Then if yee will bee rightly rich, 1. Cor. 11.23 let me aduise you, and what I haue learned of the Lord, that shall I deliuer vnto you. Mat. 6.20. Lay vp treasure for your selues in heauen, by bestowing it so as it may most glorifie your Father which is in heauen; and all this is then done, when you doe good by way of distribution, Heb. 13.16. for with these (as with sacrifices) God is pleased. All men doe know that there is enough deliuered out to the great Stewardes, to suffice the whole housholde: but they haue made that which they haue receiued, riches of iniquity; whilst by iniquity they withholde that from their brethren, which was deliuered for their brethren, themselues being but Stewardes of it, Luk. 16.1. at the most. Why then should not the bloud of the famished crye for vengeaunce more shrill then that of Abell, Gen. 4.10. seeing hee was but one, but these are many a one?

You Serpents; that are wise for your selues: Why be ye not likewise harmelesse towardes others, but thus proceede
in wronging and wringing your watri-faced brethren? Dan 4.27. Breake off your cruelty, as the Spinster doth her threed, intending to drawe it out no longer.
As God Almighty once gathered the Waters together, Gen. 1.9. Psa. 33.7. that the earth might also haue a beeing; so dooth he now restrayne the rich, least (at last) they shoulde ingrosse all.

Phillip, Phillip of Macedonia. King of Macedonia hath left fewe of his minde, that are neere his might: Who on a time lying on the grounde, and perceiuing himselfe to be of a small timbred body: said to his attendauntes: I maruell why wee couet to ingrosse so much of this world, seeing so little of it would serue our turne.
And this was found written on the Toombe of Saladine in Capitall letters: SALADINE, Saladine King of Egipt. SOMTIME KING OF EGIPT, ARABIA AND SIRIA, NOW POSSESSETH ONELY TWO VARDS OF GROVND.

Why are not men contented then, 2. Cro. 1.15. who haue siluer as plenty as stones, or when Alexander like they can command
a world, Ge. 11.4. but like these Gyants, would conquer heauen too. 1. Tim. 6.17. Deus viuens dedit nobis omnia abunde, ad vtendum. The lyuing God hath giuen vs al things aboundantly to enioy, saith the Apostle. And what would men haue more, except they desire the Deuill and all? Iob. 1.21. Our naked comming into the world, and our thredbare going out of it, are preachers to vs of the right vse of these thinges, by the small interest we haue in them. Ioh. 9.6. And yet you see, that as the Lord with clay dyd once open the eyes of the blinde, so the Deuill and the world with clay, do close vppe the sight of the seeing: a manifest signe that this clay maketh the blessing which that had. I haue seene men wipe their eyes with golde, saying that it was very soueraigne for the sight: but a wise man said, Eccle. 14.9. he that will be rich all to soone hath an ill eye, as though hee thought golde to be as infectious to the sight, as sinne is to the soule. Ios. 7 14. Such an eye had Acan; that seeing the golde at Jerico: it caused his heart to couet it, and his hand to take it.

By which place it may safely bee gathered, that all-hauing worldlings, make
onely three steps to bee wealthy. 1. A wicked eye to finde out a commoditie. 2. A bottomles heart to desire it. 3. And a sixe-fingered hand to ceaze on it. 2. Sa. 21.20. Such men oftentimes come by that they haue as honestly as Acan gat the gold which he hidde in his Tent, Ios. 7.21. who called stealing but taking, and by his hyding of it, men may gesse how honestly hee had gotten it. And true it is of all the couetous: that they steale and hyde too like Acan the sonne of Carmy.

And if they had no more steps to go vp to their lofty Towers, then to the getting of them, they would come downe like Ahazia, when hee fell through his Lattice window in his vpper Chamber at Samaria. 2. Ki, 1.2. Saul in all his proceedinges shewed himselfe a wise Politician; but when hee sinned against God grossy: 1. Sa. 13.13. Samuell telleth him that he was become a foole in so doing. And so is the wisest man if hee suffereth the thinges of this world to deceiue his heart. Haue I said to the wedge of golde thou art my confidence? Iob. 31.24. or reioyced because my portion was made great? said Iob. Yet now: what Eagle resorteth not to that Carkasse, and
whose chist holdeth not both the money and the Master too? So true is that of our Sauiour: where the treasure is, there will the heart be also. Luke. 12.34. The Lord reproouing the sinne that Dauid committed with the wife of Vria: 2. Sam. 12.8. saith, I gaue thee thy Masters house, and his wiues into thy bosome, and the houses of Iuda, and Jsraell. And might (if that had been too little) haue giuen thee so much more. Teaching all men to vse no vnlawfull meanes to get what they desire, but to sue for it at the handes of that bountifull giuer, who multiply his blessinges vpon his children, 2. Kin. 2.12. as hee did double his spirit vpon Elizeus. And yet as a net is full of birds, Ier. 5.27. so are many mens houses replenished with wealth, so gotten as Foulers get birds, and that is by deceiuing men craftily.

The Scriptures doe compare the worlds getting of wealth to hunting: as when the Prophet saith: Psal. 57.7. Euery man hunteth his brother with a net: & in hunting euery practise tendeth to the ruine of the hunted. Therfore there be dogges, Gins, and nets, but as it is gotten so thriueth it: for the wicked man shall not roast
that which he hath gotten in hunting, so small a time shall it remaine with him, and so little comfort shall he haue of it. De male quesitis, non gaudet tertius heres. Yet it is as truely said of the Vsurer as of the Hunter: that sequitur fugientia, capta relinquit, he pursueth that which would escape him, for what hee hath is sure enough. And as we vsually speake of such as run away. Caelum, non animum, mutant: They doe but change the Climate, not their conditions: Esay. 58.4. so saith Esay of Vsurers and oppressors: you doe no lesse violence after your fasting and praying then you did before them.

There was sometime dwelling in this Citty a very poore man, who being desirous to beginne the world: had (as then hee said) but one face more then a sheepe hath; but at the last hee found a friend worth eyght poundes to him. Whereof him selfe did bestowe, in fine Lynnen, fiue poundes, and his Wife in Cruels, three poundes, which in short time by retale yeelded him a noble in the pound for his Linnen. And his Wiues commodity return'd her foure shillings in the pound. But hee did
not thinke that to bee sufficient gayne. Wherefore he tooke both his commodities into his owne handes, and was like him that went to hell: fine and cruell, and in short time becommeth very rych, (for Thistels grow fast) and by this tyme sendes his sonne to the Vniuersity, who well Tutored, soone grewe rype, and being called to Paules Crosse, (lyke the gracious chylde of a gracelesse Father) Clarkelike, enuyed against damnable vsury, his Fathers professed occupation.

And when such newes were carryed to his Father (whome to haue seene at a Sermon had been greater newes) his Father replyed: I cannot iustly blame my Sonne for that he hath done, for it is aswell his profession, to speake against vsury, as it is my occupation to follow it, otherwise hee might want matter to speake on, and both my selfe and my Son might lacke money to liue on: proceed therefore my Sonne, quoth this goldfinder, and see you spare not to inuent damning arguments against such as liue by loane, and I hope that in time this wil become my trade alone.

There be many thinges in the workes of God, The vse of this. whose effects onely are knowne to vs, but the causes bee hidden from vs, as in this: That one is made rich, and another left poore: Wee know what is done heerein, but we know not why it is so done. There may be some coniectures made of the matter, but suppositions are no sound proofes: and yet may wee not thinke Gods works to be vniust, because they are vnknowne to vs. For if wee will haue patience vntill the labourers are called, we shall see that God will delyuer the penny equally to vs all. And indeed if euery man may doe what he list with his owne: much more will God deale how he will, with whom hee will. And what know we, whether the plenty which the rich haue heere, be firebrands, which God (in his wrath) hath cast at them? but if they are blessinges, Mat. 20.15. let no mans eye bee euill because GOD is good.

div.head: Text.

q.hi: That was clothed in Purple and fine White.

div.p: IT is true (by warrant of holy writ) that if any may pleade state by their apparell, the rich may doe it, Mat. 11.8. for when our Sauiour said, that such as weare silken rayments are in Kings Courts, hee ment their attyre was befitting their state, and teacheth vs that such garments doe best become our person, as most agree with our calling. And that all thinges should be ordered after his pleasure that taught vs to pray: Luk. 11.2. Iam. 2.2. Thy will be done. Saint Iames, vnder the names of a silken cote, and vile rayment, vnderstandeth a difference betwixt the rich and the poore, while they soiourne heere on earth. As if he should say: Mat. 6.19. The rich Moth-feeders & Cankerbreeders, doe vse to shewe their pompe by their apparell, their hearts are as full of pride, as their bagges are of gold, and they will haue the world to knowe it too.

Therefore said Paul to Timothie: 1. Tim. 6.17.
Charge them that are rich, that they be not high minded, and that they trust not in vncertaine riches. Two sinnes was the rich sort infected withall especially; With a vaine confidence in vaine riches, which the Apostle saith, none ought to put any trust in, because they are vncertaine: the Thames doth both ebbe and flowe in foure and twenty houres without faile, but no man can tel when a Bank-rout shall flowe, if hee be at an ebbe: Again, the Thames hath neuer so low a fall, but it hath as high a flood: but if a rich man fall, his floode is sildome recouered to the full. Therefore rich men haue no reason to bee high minded because of their wealth, yet it is as proper to wealth as to witte, to puffe vppe fleshe and blood, with the blaste of vaine-glory. Yea, so high doth the mind of the mighty lift vp their lookes, that they looke quite ouer the poore, and neuer see them or not regard them (at the least:) and as the wickednesse of all the wealthy is for the most part Capitall, so the sinne of Citizens, are lofty sinnes especially. Esay. 26.5. Wherefore God called them
high-minded Citizens. Esai. 26.5. Psa. 132.1. Lord I am not high-minded, I haue no proude lookes said the Psalmist, as if hee would haue said an high minde is discernable by a proude countinaunce, or the countenaunce is the Callender of the minde. And so ment Esay when hee said of the impudent sinners, Esai. 3.39. their countenaunce bewrayeth them, &c. Your religion lyeth in your mouthes, for the most part; and your wealth in your heartes: Like those whome the holy Ghost pointing out to Ezekiell, Eze. 33.31. said: Sonne of man they speake well of thee, but their harts, runneth after their couetousnesse. Or as Ieremie saith of the people in his time, Ierimie. 5.2. that they did acknowledge that the Lord liueth, but yet would sweare to deceiue: Ostentant pietatem, non ostendunt pietatem. They will talke of Godlynes as much as any, but they walke in goodnes as little as any, for the empty caske maketh more rumbling then the full. Yea it is as true of them as of Rome: that, Religio peperit diuitias et filia deuorau • t matrem: the blessing of the Gospell hath made them wealthy, and the
Daughter hath deuoured the mother. And nowe wealth hath begotten that drunken sinne of pride, which all the Props in the world are too weake to support.

As you see in the Prophesie of Esay, Esai. 3.16. 2. Sa. 14.26. and much like is it to Absolons hayre, that was too heauie for his head, vntill at last his head was too heauy for his body too, 2. Sam. 18.9. which teacheth that people infected with pride are neuer weary of it, vntill it be weary of them: 2. Ki. 9.30.33 2. Sam. 18.9. Iessabel dyed with a painted face, and Absalon in his long haire.

So God was as good as his word, that he once spake by his Prophet Sophonie: Cap. 1.8. I will visite the Princes and the Kings children, and all that attire themselues strangely. By the word, Visit: God meaneth that such are growne out of order, for visitation tendeth to reformation. Now as this & al other scriptures like to this do teach, that God will not endure these abuses, so knowe you, that too much trimming of the outwarde man, is a manifest token, that the inwarde man is abridged of his
inward grace. And this principle being as true in diuinity as in humanity, that the variety of thinges argueth the verye vanity of them, inferreth by a necessary consequent, that much variety of apparell, is proofe enough of a minde surfeyted with vanity. We cannot immagine any man or woman to bee so banckrout of sence, but if they be not honest indeed, yet they would bee accounted so at the least: sith then our apparell, and other outward demeanor calleth our life into question, euen in pollicy it were good, to beware what garments we weare, but specially because religiō wil iudge vs, for who wil say they are mortified inwardly to God, which liue a loose life in the face of the world? Ornamentum est quod ornat, or nat autem quod honestat: An Ornament is that which becommeth vs, and that becommeth vs which wee may weare with honestie, saith one. It were good then, that such as care not for christianity, would suite themselues with modesty, and not giue the world occasion to thinke that they liue, onely to liue vnhonestly: this sinne of pride consisteth
either in strangenes of fashiō, like the Babilonish garment which Acan conueyed, or in superfluity of matter, as when they lay on cost, like Iulia, that would not forget that shee was the Emperours daughter, though her father (as she said) forgat that he was the Emperour: or as our superfluous Dames that thinke they bee best regarded, whose Gownes are most garded: or like the bouncing breeched Gentles, that make garmentes (as Assuerus made his feast,) Hest. 1.4. to shew theyr ability: but, ad quid deliciae vestrae: to what vse serue all your vanities? Euery man seeth saue they that eyther will not see, or dare say nothing if they see, because Assuerus decree is of no force in their houses: Hest. 1.22. the husband is many times constrained to looke out of his house, as an Owle out of a bush; daring onely see, but not bee seene; Such women Esay cheeketh, with: Esay. 32.9. Vp you rich and idle women, for they will not worke vntill they haue brought their husbandes from plenty to beggery: faire burdens are they, not cracking the backe, but quite breaking the necke of their husbandes
credit, de albatasepulcra, goodly graues to burie all their husbands wealth in.

div.head: Text.

q.hi: And fared verie deliciouslie euerie day.

div.p: It is a great blessing of God to haue meate and drinke at all, and it is a greater blessing to haue it of the best, but to haue it euery daie, is to be blessed in the suparlatiue degree.

And yet I do not so cal these blessings, as if I thought all men blessed, that liue in aboundance: for there are men that haue goods, and not the grace how to vse them: Eccle. 4.8. such a mans wealth is good in respect of the giuer, but ill in respect of the receiuer, goods they are because they fare well by them, but euils, because their plenty relieueth not others pouerty; For when men fare well, they should remember them that fare ill: As Nehemia said at the feast of Tabernacles. God is neuer more dishonored then in that time of merriment, as if you looke with the
spectacles of discretion, Eze. 16.49. Iob. 1.5. you may see in those sinnes of Sodom. Therefore Iob had reason to respect (as he said he did) that his Sonnes had dishonored God in their feastes. Whē did you euer heare of a greater Eclipse to the honor of God then at the Reuels on Herods birth day? Mat. 14.16. You knowe howe good a man lost his head at that feast. Goe to then, you that fare deliciouslie euery day, you that haue that which is both dainty and plentie, feeding on the quintessence of Gods giftes; You whose tongue doth taste of whatsoeuer it can talke off; You that thinke you are borne onely to go gailie, and feed finely; You that fare the better for all thinges, and yet nothing fareth the better for you. 2. Kin. 2.15. As the children of the Prophets applauded Elisha for his goodnesse, so all condemne you for your exceeding badnesse: And as the poore in Jobs time blessed him for his bounty, Iob. 31.20. so the needy of our age curse you for your cruelty, and that iustly too, seeing you are without all excuse, for doing good. 2. Sam. 25.8. For could a man come to Naball in a fitter time then at his
Sheep shering? or to a meeter man then such a one, as hath for euery day in the weeke a seuerall suite, and for Sunday two? or that feedeth on dainties euery daye? I cannot see saith Saint Iames, Ia. 2.15.16. how these men can (with a quiet conscience) goe gorgiously, fare daintily, and talke religiouslie, and yet answere Iesus Christ in his members, with God send you meate and warmth. Make your selues garmentes of God send you cloth, and see if they will keep you warme: or sit downe to dinner with your Table full of God send you meate, and looke if you shall not rise, as hungry as you sat down? seeing then, the rich are not described by what they haue not; but by that they haue, such as answere the needy with, I haue not for you, they send God word they loue him not, 2. Sa. 25.10. as Naball did to Dauid, that he knew him not. If there bee first a willing minde, 2. Cor. 8.12. it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not, saith the Apostle: but if a man hath this worldes goods, 1. Ioh. 3.17. and seeing his brother want, shutteth his compassion from him: howe
dwelleth the loue of God in him saith S. Iohn.

Our Sauiour accompteth that done to himselfe, Mat. 25.40. which is done to poore Christians, as men acknowledge themselues satisfied, when money is paide to their seruantes, for their vse. And in commaunding that hee which hath twoo coates, Luk. 3.11. should bestowe one vpon him that hath none: hee ment that no estates should keepe to themselues, more then they need, and that all degrees should be furnished with so much as they lacke, and as Christianity mooueth all men to giue willingly, 2. Cor. 9.7. for God loueth a chearefull giuer: so duety commaundeth the needy to receiue thankfully, contrary to the nine, Luk. 17.18. which were deliuered from theyr Leprosie.

When Sampson had taken houny out of the Lyons Carkasse he said out of the eater commeth meate, Iudg. 4.14. but from our eaters commeth no meate, 1. Cor. 15.32 but they make themselues merry with, let vs eate and drinke, for to morrow we shall dye; Iob. 1.4. They haue gotten the tricke of Iobs children to feast their own, and to banquet none,
but such as doe feast them againe: and so these Capon-eaters make their bellies as graues, to bury the bodies, of beastes, foules and fishes. They care not who fast, Philoxenus. so they may feaste, wishing (like Philoxenus) that they had neckes as long as Cranes, that they might long taste their sweet meates in going downe.

div.head: Text.

epigraph.q: And there was a certaine begger named Lazarus, which lay at his gate full of sores, desiring to be refreshed, with the crummes that fell from his boord, but no man gaue them him.

div.p:
YOu know, he that giueth all thinges once, Ioh. 4.7. craued a draught of water, not for that he needeth vs, but for that oftentimes he trieth vs, neither doth he try vs, as being ignoraunt of our affections, but because he would manifest to vs our manifolde infections: and now ye haue as great vse of the poore, as they haue
of you, therefore the Lorde vttered these two Scriptures. Mar. 14.7. Luk. 16.9. The poore you shall haue alwaies with you: and, Make you friends of the riches of iniquitie. Teaching vs howe to conceaue of the poore on earth, who shall receiue vs into heauen: That they may receiue you into euerlasting habitations when you shall haue need. And our Sauiour was borne as poore as wee, that he might make vs as rich as he; then let not plenty reuile, but relieue pouerty, as the state wherein our highest Lord was born, for so meaneth the holy ghost, that guest of all good mindes; though the gracelesse sort of our age, do measure mens worthinesse, by their wealthinesse, and saye that the needye people are naughtie ones: but if that were so, the Sonne of man, not hauing wheron to reste his heade, fasting long, and beeing tempted of the Deuill and all, should bee as bad, as hee was poore.

I neuer knewe you saith hee, Ma. 7.23. to them that knewe not the poore, and deliuering the wounded man to the Innekeeper, hee gaue him money and this
charge withall: Cura hunc, take care of him. Luk. 10.35.

Now as their need is exceeding great, so should their reliefe be very much. Lazarus is called a begger, you are called rich men, heere is as much contrariety as may be: very pouerty in the one, and very plenty in the other: then as the Cherubins ouer the mercy seate, were like one to another, so are the riche and the poore: Gen. 1.26. both resembling the image of God; in respect of your seuerall dueties, your poore bretheren are as the Arke, you as the Cherubins, 1. Ki. 8.7. vnder whose wings of mercy they should bee shrowded: but in regard of their present state, they are more like to Daniell, Dan. 6.16. when hee laye at the mercy of the hungry Lyons.

My Father worketh hitherto, Ioh. 5.17. and I worke saith our Lord, for though they rested from creating, yet they cease not from blessing, doing good to the creatures; So should you omitte no time wherein, or occasion whereby you may helpe such as haue need of you, that the poore may say of you for your well doing,
as the Licaonians said of Paul and Barnabas, for their heauenly speaking, Actes. 14.12. the Gods are come downe to vs in the shape of men; for men come neerest vnto God in shewing mercy one to another. Esay. 42.3. It is some charitie not to breake a bruised Reede, but to binde it vp is much mercy.

div.head: Text.
div.p:
THat this poore man is named in the Scripture, & the rich man hath no name therein, but is spoken off by the holy Ghost, as men discribe strangers by circumstances: it firmely noteth, the truth of Saint Iohns Prophesie, who saith that as many as had not their names written in the book of Life, Apoc. 20.15 were cast into the Lake of fire. Againe, it noteth in what case or state of liuing they are, to whome we must doe good, namely to Lazers; or the housholde of pouertie: and therefore this needy brother is described by such accidentes as are incident
to pouerty, and doe rightly Annothomize a man in miserie: As that hee laye at the gate, not beeing able to stand.

Such were the Cripples of whome Saint John saith, Ioh. 5.3. that they did lye wayting for the moouing of the water of the Poole Bethesda, and that Lame man, whome GOD by Peter and John did heale, Act. 3.6. was brought by others, and layed at the Temples beautifull Gate: all such doe shewe their impotency, by couching on the ground. It is duety to doe good to all men, but it is both duety and mercy to relieue men in miserie.

Heere then, is one sort of poore whom we must sustaine: such as haue no means to get their liuing according to Gods ordinaunce. Therefore this Lazer begged for almes, Act. 3.6. and hee at Ierusalem was layde at the Gate of purpose to aske almes of such as passed by him and such a one was Bartimeus that begged by the way side and many moe. There is also a sort of poore that doe worke, but their labour is not sufficient to relieue
them, eyther by reason of the hardnesse of mens heartes, who make them performe too much woorke for too little money, or else because life-stealing age, hath taken away the wonted nimblenesse of their fingers, and agillity of the bodye. Such the Scripture saith are strucken in age, 1. Kin. 1.1. and when age striketh, the people bende, as they that seeke where they may lye downe and rest. 1. Cor. 16. Such Saint Paule spake off when hee wrote to the Corinthians about a Collection for their better maintenaunce, for such as cannot liue of their owne labour, ought to bee maytained by the common pursse: As the Lacedemonians had a custome, that the very oxen which had laboured for them vntill for very age they were not able to worke any longer, should without molestation feede in any mans pasture.

And another sort of poore there are, which like the Prodigall childe, Luk. 15.13. once thought their bagge had no bottom, but when they found a bottom, they perceiued also that it is too late to spare in the
bottome. These may wel complaine but hardly be heard, for though their case be pittifull poore, yet the cause of it was pittilesse prodigallity: and who will bemone his case whose cause is naught? That wise of the sonne of the Ptophet, which intreated assistance of Elisha, 2. King. 4.1. after the death of her husband, alleadged that though he dyed in debt yet he feared the Lord, and that (as shee said) Elisha did know: whereby it might appeare that he ran not into debt by vnlawful meanes nor spent what he borrowed in riotous company: for if it had been so, Elisha had been able to reprooue her, and it is not vnlike but that hee would haue so done, but they that foster such as care not how they get, nor how they spend; they maintaine pouerty, but not the poore. There is yet an other sort of poore, who as they neede exceedingly, so will they take extreame courses to supply their want, these without blushing say: Luk. 16.3. to begge, I am not so base minded, and digge I cannot, these are they that steale and be hanged.

We vsually say there be two kindes of
enough, and so is the saying of Salamon, Pro. 28.19. he that tilleth his ground shal haue plenty of bread, but he that followeth idlenes shall haue pouerty enough: Among the auncient Romaines, no man might walke the streetes without some instrument: that signified, by what trade hee got his liuing: and in Indea at this day euery man is examined what hee hath earned before he is suffered to eate. Our idle ones should take example by God himself, who wrought first, Exo. 20.21. & then rested: yea he wrought sixe daies, and rested the seauenth; so were it meete that they should worke more, and rest lesse: and doubtlesse our Sauiour in saying to the Diciples not onely rest, Mar. 6.31. but rest a while: meant to teach men to measure their ease aswell as their paines: the very Angels haue no idle allowance, but are as they bee named ministring spirits, and seeing the greatest states both in heauen and in earth, haue the heauiest burdens: Heb. 1.14. no maruell if the Scripture condemneth them that lend not a finger to ease other.

If that law were in execution, hee that
will not labour let him not eate: 2. The. 3.10. I warrant you more would dye of idlenesse then of sicknesse. I am of his minde that was of my name, and said sometimes there is not a more vnnaturall thing then to suffer these Catterpillers to gnaw on the common wealthes fruite, by whome it neuer receiued fruite. One argument more of this mans impotency, is that he was full of sores: there are a Pocky company that are sore at this day: but it is very like, Iob. 2.7. that this man had his sores sent (as Job. were) for tryall of his patience, and to exercise others pitty towards him, for the diseased haue most neede to be eased: as our Sauiours manifolde examples doe signifie, which hee partly shewed on the woman with the bloudy issue: Mat 9.22. J •• . 4.39. Mar 7.35. Mat. 8.13. Mat. 9.7. Mat. 17.8. on the man deafe and dombe; on Peters mother in Law; the Senturions seruant; the man taken with a Palsie; the Lunaticke, and the like: and if men will not helpe them, the very dogges will doe what lyeth in them, before they shall want all comfort.

It is proper to dogges to wound, but
heere vnkindnesse woundeth, and dogs giue plaisters; Iudge then, whether Diues or his dogges, were more dogged. And to leaue this miser without all excuse, his poore man is said, to craue the crummes, lying at his gate, so that in comming foorth he must needs see him; and considering what hee asked, could not with any colour deny him. What poore man euer lay at my gare, and perished for want of reliefe, through my default (said Iob?) but if our rich men should aske this question, Iob. 31.21. it would bee aunswered euery day to their endles shame.

For as Christ passing by the way from Jerico, sawe two blinde men: so our able men, seeing such, passe by them apace. 1. Sa. 11. Nahash hath gotten their right eyes that they cannot see such, Sathan standeth at their right hand, Psa. 99.5. therefore they can doe no good to any. God saith, aske and you shall haue, Mat. 7.7. putting vs in minde of our best state, while we are heere on earth, for al are in respect of God, as the poore are in comparison of the rich, for the proudest
are faine to say to God, giue vs this day our daily bread, Lu. 11.3. as the poore humbleth himselfe to the rich, when he wold haue aught: 1. Cor. 4.4. Quid enim habent quod non acceperunt: and it is the greatest motiue to make vs shew mercy to other, if wee consider that both wee haue had, and looke to receiue mercy our selues from other.

Now seeing Lazarus beggeth but the crummes, and yet obtaineth not, it agrauateth this mans sinne like an Orator: for if such a fellowe as cogging Gehesy, craueth a double gift, 2. Ki. 5.23. hee is answered, take (with all my heart) what will serue your turne; so cunningly can rich men serue their owne turne, vnder a colour of seruing yours: Yee see what a vaine man will doe in his humour, Mar. 6.23. Herod will giue halfe his Kingdome for a daunce: the rich man will do any thing to please himself, but he wil do nothing to please God. Loe hee will not pleasure a poore man with his poore crummes, for it is said that no man gaue them vnto him: it seemeth that the seruants were like the Master: and no marueil, for an irreligious
master often maketh an vngodlie seruant: and a wretched husband a miserable wife: But it is not alwaies so, for cruell Ahab, 1. Kin. 18.3. had good O badia to his Steward, and hoggish Naball, had kinde Abigall to wife. 1. Sa. 25.18. 1. Kin. 18.4. While Iesabell plagued the Prophets, Obadia cherisheth them. But now, where most is, nothing commeth to the poore mans lot. Lord where is charity become? that men will not giue that to their brethren, which they cast to their dogges? Mat. 3.9. O God raise vp children to Abraham, make fleshly hearts of the flinty ones, by causing the fire of that spirit, which proceedeth out of thy mouth, to kindle the coles of mans kay-colde conscience: for he that prayed, Ier. 31.18. conuert thou me and I shall bee conuerted; ment that it must bee of thy doing or neuer be done.

No maruell if the poore doe pine, when the riche repine, to depart from their crummes: Act. 20.35. the Scripture saith it is a more blessing to giue then to take: so that eyther the rich beleeueth not the Scriptures, or careth not for a blessing: if otherwise, considering how little wold
pleasure a poore body, and how much it would please God; I cannot see howe they could denye so bounden a duety, and so reasonable a request, for neither can the poor aske lesse then the crūmes, nor the rich giue lesse, except they will giue nothing, there is no doubt but God would be as well pleased that you giue your broken meate, Lu. 21.3. as he was with her that gaue but two poore mites. There be many that would bee accompted doers of good: but where may we finde a faithfull man, Pro. 20.6. saith the wise Salomen, as if he would say, many would bee said to be bountifull benefactors, and yet do nothing that is good, but you must do so, as ye would be accompted so, or else when men haue found you, they are neuer the neere one faithfull man. Mat. 23.23. The Scribes and Pharises, pretended most godlines, (you know) when they intended exceeding wickednes and the world is full of such holy theeues. It was for our example that our Lord said, Mat, 15.22. I haue compassion on the people, for they haue been with me now three daies and haue eaten nothing, what compassion then should we take of them
that haue begged from doore to doore, all the daies of their life: you chasten thē with whips, but their father will chasten you with Scorpions, Ier. 8. for your vnmercifulnes towards them. Vsually mens charity is proportionable to their faith, Mat. 13.31. for whose faith is not so great, as a graine of Mustardseede, there charity is not worth one crrumme of bread.

Christ was knowne in breaking of bread, & Esay maketh it a true note, Luk. 24.35. Esay. 58.7. of a Christian to break his bread to the hungry. And look vpon the fig-tree, & all other trees saith our Sauiour, Lu. 21.29. for whē they shoote out, Sommer draweth neere: and I doubt not, but a fruitefull life to Godward, is an infallible token, that men drawe neere to Gods kingdome, and it to them; therefore such as haue begun well must continue well also, least their latter negligence, depriue them of the blessings of their former diligence: but such as neuer giue a blessing, Iam. 2.13. let them neuer looke to receiue a blessing.

It is almost come to passe, in all the land, as it was in Diues house, that no man giueth any thing to any poore man,

and yet they that haue already too much, are most hastie to haue from euery man. How then would you haue them content that possesse nothing, seeing your selues liue mal-content, which enioy al things? Non ad erubescentiam vestram dictum est? Doe you not-blush when you consider this?

Pharoes leane Kine deuoured the fat? Ga 41.4. and no maruell, for the leane should feede vpon the fat, that they may be fatter: But when the fat eate vp the leane, there is no cause of that: Againe, seauen did eate seauen in Pharoes dreame, and so each one did eate one, but we see nowe, that a fewe fat ones chop vp all the wealth, and the most may goe beg, hange, or steale, or starue: and if they beg you cry a whip for them, if they steale a rope: but if they starue, you shall burne for it in the fire of hel; for you may keep most of them from begging, stealing, staruing or hanging if you will, but so deep is your foundation laide in vnmercifulnesse, that an earth-quake cannot mooue you.

He that gaue you a commandement
of mercy, gaue you also an example of mercy; for hee said not onely, Lu. 6.36. bee you mercifull, but added, as your heauenly Father is mercifull: For as God bestoweth not one blessing vpon vs, but multiplieth them as he thinketh meetest: so he would haue all remember to grow in goodnes, and hauing done one charitable deed, to be-thinke vs what goodnes wee may doe next with most proffit to our brother, and pleasure to our God: as when the Lord had said, Lu. 3.11. let him that hath two coates, giue one to him that hath none: he proceedeth to say, and let him that hath meat, do likewise. Though you loue your honey because it is sweet, yet might you giue some of it, Pro. 20.27. seeing your selues are glutted with it. Omnis virtutis laus in actione Consistat: Vertue is no longer praised, then it is exercised: Iob. 30.20. Iob. 31.20. other mens wordes may honor you, but your owne good deeds, must make you right honorable.

When Alexander offered fifty Tallents to his friend Perillus, Alexander. as a Dowry with his Daughter: Perillus said tenne Tallents were enough: Yea said Alexander
for thee to take, but not for mee to giue. We haue but a few of this minde, eyther to aske lesse then is offered, or to offer more then is asked; but so honorable is euery Eagle, that hee will not eate his pray, Ecclesia. 4.8. alone without company of other birds. Riches may be kept to the hurt of him that hath them. Therefore the wise venture the worst to saue the better, as he that fighteth, holdeth out his arme to defend his head; Acts. 27.38. as the Saylers caste out their corne to saue their Ship; or as the true man parteth from his purse to keepe his life; and so the rich men should doe good heere, that they may not suffer ill heere after: My heart shall not reprooue me of my daies (said Iob) meaning that his conscience should not witnesse, Iob. 27.6. that hee had spent his time ill. I would they would once bee of that minde, who are as euill as olde; but as the Lord began his Sermon, Luke. 4.21. (in the Sinogogue of Nazareth) with this day, is this Scripture fulfilled in your eares, so may I truely say euery day, is this Scripture fulfilled before your eyes, for Quo plura hominibus contulit Dei bonitas
Occecat animos altior securitas: And I appeale euen to their owne consciences, (if they haue any) whether thousandes of golde and siluer, Psa. 119.27. or Gods law bee dearer vnto the rich. All men holde it a good rule to denye nothing that wee would aske, and to require nothing that wee would deny being asked. But the vnmercifull, will haue no nay like Ahab, and Iessabell, nor giue any yea, 2. Kin. 20.11 if he should part from any thing, like Naball the churle, for all goodnes goeth backward, 2. Kin. 20.11 Esay. 51.21. like the shadowe vpon Ahaz Dyall. So miserable and drunken are men, (that is) so drunken with miserablenesse are they.

If you aske why the hand is bountifull, it is because the heart is pittifull, for that heart is colde, that setteth not the hand a worke; there is a heart that is like the clay, for it will be harder and harder: such a one was Pharoes heart: and there is a heart like waxe, which will melt vpon the brethren, 2. Cro. 34.27 such a heart had King Iosia; and such hearts haue all they, who are throughly touched with a seeling of other mens wants.

And as Samuel powring oyle on Saules head, 1. Sa. 10.1. said the Lord hath annointed thee: so the world giueth wealth, but God it is that blesseth you to doe good with it. O that my complaint were truely wayed, Iob. 6.2. said Job, and it were to bee wished, that men had grace indeede to make a conscience of the poore mans case: then as Samuell said to Saule, 1. Sa. 20.7. when thou seest these signes come vpon thee, doe as occasion shall serue: So they would bestowe bread vpon the hungry, drinke vpon the thirsty, and cloathing vppon the ragged, fitting their abilitie (like Almners) to euery good oportunity, whereas nowe the poore finde them no more then Job did his visiters, Iob. 16.2. a company of miserable comforters.

div.head: Text.

q.hi: And it hapned that the begger dyed.

div.p:
THough it be heere said, that it hapned or chaunced, that the poore man dyed: for that death eyther commeth sodainely, before we looke for it, or on the party that is not prouided to it: yet the originall saith, it came to passe, or so it was, that Lazarus dyed, therefore as Jsacke said to Esau his eldest sonne, Gen. 27.2. I am olde and knowe not the day of my death: so your vse of this is to remember, that death tarrieth not, and that the couenant of the graue is not shewed vnto you, Eccle. 14.12. that you may beare a part with Dauid. O God my heart is ready, Psa. 108.1. my heart is ready, for as he was prepared to glorifie God by liuing well, so should all by dying well: and the departure of such, is like the counsell that Rebecca gaue to Iacob to rid them out of danger, Gen. 27.43. least the better should be molested of the worse: and in dying, there is a kinde of necessity, 1. Cor. 15.50 for seeing that flesh and blood cannot
not inherit the Kingdome of God, as it is but flesh and bloud, it must therefore haue an alteration, not of substance but of quallity, insteed of corruption, the body taking an incorruptible State, and in place of mortality, it shall put on life it selfe.

And our Sauiour said, that death was necessary euen in his man-hood: Except the wheate corne falleth into the ground and dyeth, Ioh. 12.24. it abideth alone: so, Corruptio vnius est generatio, alterius: It pleaseth the holy Ghost by killing our imperfections, to begette in vs a perfecte state.

And seeing that God hath promised a better life to them that vse this well, the godly are glad to restore this, that they may receiue that: and in this sence it is truely said, that the houre of death, is better then the houre of birth: for it is better to the better, seeing that the liuing doe sinne and are mortall, but such as haue dyed in the fayth, haue made an ende of sinning, and are immortall.

And death being a debt that all must
pay, if it bee any degree of blessednesse to be out of debt, then they that are soonest dead are sooner happy. For as the bad dye to shorten impiety, and to beginne their paine so the better depart to ende their misery, and begin felicity. The Apostle instructing the ignoraunce of the Thessalonians, conserning the state of such as haue departed in the faith, calleth their bodily death a sleepe: 1. Thes. 4.13 Ioh. 11. for as the people sayd of Lazarus, if hee sleepeth hee shall doe well, so what man or Woman is impatient to see theyr friendes, kindred, or acquaintaunce sleepe and rest quietly? so patientlye should all take the death one of an other, as those that haue bidden the world good-night, and are gone to sleepe for a time. Beare wee then, the losse of our friendes with this resolution: that as sure as the earth hath lost them, heauen haue found them, and though they haue not the company of men, yet they haue the comfort of Angels, which is far better.

Heere their foundations were on the
sandes, and therfore their earthly Tabernacles fell, Psa 87.1. but nowe their foundations are on the holy hilles, where they shall continue: they are in heauen, where nothing can annoy them: as the other are in hell, where nothing may ioy them.

div.head: Text.

epigraph.q: And was carried by the Angels into Abrahams bosome,

div.p:
WHen the tempter assaulted the Lord with, Mat. 4. if thou be the Son of God, &c. he alleadged also that Scripture which affirmeth the dilligence of Angels in their office, Psa. 91.11. which the Author to the Hebrues saith, Heb. 1.14. is to waite on such as shall be heyres of Saluation: the truth wherof is confirmed, by many plaine demonstrations. Luk. 22.43. For Iesus Christ beeing in an agony, hath an Angell sent to comfort him. 1. Ki. 19.5.6. Daniell. 6. Elias in distresse, is relieued by an Angell. When Daniell was in danger of the Lyons, he said that an Angell stopped their mouthes. Gen. 32.1. And Iacob flighted with a feare of his brother Esau, is encouraged
raged by a vision of Angels: and poore Lazarus departing out of this life, the honorable Angels were his bearers into rich Abrahams bosome. So that the departure of the faithfull out of this life, 2. Kin. 2.11. is like the passage of Elias in his glorious Chariot. Be we therefore stayed vpon Gods good prouidence who neuer leaueth his, Ab ouo, ad aeuum, for he spake by long experience, that sayd, I haue been young, and now am olde: Psa. 37.25. yet neuer saw I the righteous forsaken, nor his seede begging their bread. Be we also admonished to perseuer in wel doing, least our latter negligence, cut vs off from the blessing of our former diligence: and accursed conuersation, depriue vs of the assistance and societie of the blessed Angels.

Now the place whithere the poore Lazarus was carried, is the possession and fruition, of the rest of the faithfull, after this life; Which heere the Lord calleth Abrahams bosome: Lu. 25.2. and else where is named our Lords ioy, and eternal rest, and our Fathers house. Concerning which place; as the righteous
haue heard of it, Apoc. 14.13 Ioh. 14.2. Psa. 48.8. so haue some of them seene in it very excellent thinges, they knowe, that as the state wee ayme at, is heere incomprehensible, so it is there incomparable. Psa. 103.5. Where hee that made the soule, will satisfie it with good thinges, Psa. 16.11. for in his presence is the fulnes of ioy, and at his right hand is pleasure for euermore.

And because this place must be gotten by belieuing: therefore it is likened to the bosome of Abraham the Father of the Faithfull: and the Chyldren of GOD doe relie them on fayth, Ioh. 13.23. as Saint Iohn did on Christes bosome: and Lazarus on Abrahams. For they remember that their inflicted punishmente, is no way comparable to thev nexpected comfort, which he promised: Ioh. 16.22. who said, I will see you againe, and your heartes shall reioyce, and your ioy shall no man take from you; if any thing could dispence with death, holines could doe it. But the very elect of God though they liue like Saintes, Psa. 82.7. must dye like men.

How be it, right precious in his eyes
is their departure. Psa. 116.13. The wise man bringeth in the fooles opinion concerning the death of such as poore Lazarus was. Wisd. 5.4. Wee thought him to perish (saie they) Non autem periunt a terra, sed seperantur a Populo, vt Colleganter ad patres: They are not destroyed from off the earth, but are parted from other folke, that they might bee ioyned with their Fathers. Where they shall not chuse but liue, as heere they may not chuse but dye. For such honour haue all Gods Saintes: and such blessednesse hath Abrahams bosome: and as that is deerest vnto vs, which we place neerest to vs, so must the fayth of Abraham, Contio diui bring vs to the bosome of Abraham.

div.head: Text.
div.p: TEndimus huc omnes, metam properamus ad vnam: This word, also: importeth the equallity of all estates, in respect of death: Iob. 12.2. therefore you that are men alone, and thinke there is no wisedome without you, preuent this decree if you can, or else confesse your infirmity. Purchase a new lease, with all the bagges that euer you filled, or else make you bagges that waxe not olde; You rich men haue wit enough to keep your money from such as sell you leases, vntill you haue gotten (confirmed vnder their handes and seales by good assuraunce) what you would haue: but in spirituall cases, yee are as ignoraunt as Asses.

Wherefore else did the worldes childe, Luk. 12. take vpon him to warrant himselfe a long life, when hee must dye the next night: did not the spirit of God
rightly reprooue him, with (Stulte Diues) thou foolish rich man? for what greater folly, then to thinke your selues to bee sure of that whereof euery man is most vncertaine?

You see that forbearaunce is none acquittaunce, for though the poore man dyed first, yet the rich man dyed also: and the time will come when all shall speake in the present-tence, 1 Kin. 2.2. Iob. 7.21. like Dauid and Job: I goe the way of all the earth, saith the one; and beholde nowe must I sleep in the dust, saith the other: So the greatest of you shall come from his Downe bed, to his dust bed, at the last, whē death shal come, 2. Ki. 9 24. like the arrow frō Jehu his bow, which strooke Ioram, that he tumbled downe in his Chariot and dyed.

Where is his promise then, Gen. 3. that soothed vp our progenitors, with you shall not dye. Is not this true rather? it is appointed vnto men, Heb. 13.27 that they shall once dye. Which being Gods decree, it standeth vnchangeable, Dan. 6. like the lawes of the Medes and Persians, which might not be altered: or like Pilates inscription
on Christe his Crosse: or as Herods oath, that for his credits sake hee would not breake: or like Iephthaes vowe, which for religions sake he thought hee might not alter. Iam. 1.17. So with God is no variablenesse, and therefore are his couenants called couenantes of salt. 2. Cro. 13.5. Seeing then the case standeth so with vs, that all estates are equally subiecte to deathes stroke, let none thinke it more strange to dye, (when their time is come) then to goe to bedde when night is come. Yet this is the vsuall ouer-sight of the rich, that they rather consider how much longer they might haue liued: like her that said, Ioh. 11.21. Lord if thou hadst been heere, my brother had not been dead. Then howe much sooner they might haue dyed, like him that said, Psa. 31.15 our time is in Gods hand, who being bound to no man, yet is bountifull to all men, that we might attribute it to his mercy without our merite.

The Lord blessing them that liue in his feare; Psa. 128.2. saith of such, they shall eate the labour of their handes, and how much more may hee plucke that, which his
owne hand hath planted, specially seeing life is so committed vnto vs that we only vse it but God is the owner of it, who holdeth the property of life in him selfe, who is the life it selfe: and the Scripture aduertiseth by the example of giuing tribute to Caesar, Mat. 22.21. that the right of the lawfull Soueraigne, is an effectuall reason to make euery loyall subiect to giue him his duety.

And the consideration of the weake tenor, that we haue of this life, may be a forecible motiue, to perswade vs to vse it well, while we haue it; for he that liueth and not by righteousnes shall dye, Iob. 4.21. & not in goodnes, saith Iob.

O then, by a good conuersation furnish your life against death shall finish it. At other times wee teach you to liue well, but vppon these occasions we admonish you to dye well. Wee all doe passe our dayes, as Peter and the other Disciple which went to the Sepulchre. Ioh. 20.6. For some goe both to the Graue and into the Graue; others goe to the Graue onely, but not into it.

And as when you accompany the dead corpes to be buried, it goeth before and you come after: So may you be aduertised that you shall follow in dying, as well as in going: as when death had done with the poore man, it singled out the rich man, for the rich man also dyed, saith the Euangelist.

Thus when you heare of one that is dead, you must thinke of it as a summons to your owne. And for such as liue well, it is as profitable for themselues that they shall dye heereafter, as it is for the poore and others that they liue heere, and that doe they know well enough. Wherefore in the spirits of iust men, they say: Cupio dissolui, et esse cum Christo, not Cupio mori; Rom. 6.23. I desire to dye: for death is the reward of Sinne, but to be dissolued, for the soule is in the body, as a birde is in the cage, Psa. 11.1. seeking to bee at liberty, and being let out, flyeth vnto the hill: or as Joseph in the prison house desiring inlargement. Gen. 40.14. O bring my soule out of prison, Psa. 142.9. saith the Prophet. And a true distinction of the liues of the better from the worse, while they liue heere: is, that
the one may be said to suffer this life, the other to desire it: for the one cryeth like the Saints; come Lord Iesu, Apoc. 22. come quickly. The other like the Deuils, what haue wee to doe with thee the Sonne of the liuing God? and this is an infallible truth? Luk. 8.28. that a mans willingnesse to dye, doth (for the most part) argue his preparednesse vnto God.

Now a common case, is a common comfort, therefore seeing that poore & rich and all must dye, that is no iniury to any, which is the equall condition of all. And in that, that the poore man was first taken: and then the rich man, it noteth that God respecteth not persons, either in life or in death, but would teach vs to take our turne when our time is come: and so much the rather for that death is the common Ferry man of vs all. It was an effecte of Gods vnsearchable wisedome, that as hee did seale vp the certainty of our death: Iob. 3.23. so he concealed the time of our dying, thereby admonishing vs, to respect death as a decree most certaine, and to expect it as a thing most vncertaine, that both being well regarded
might prepare vs to a readinesse. For though we know that all shall dye: yet we see that all haue not equall time, for one dyeth in the wombe, Psa. 58.8. euen that vntimely fruite of a woman: an other at his first step into the world, taking his welcome and fare well both at once: others after a little while, whose cradle figureth their graue; and others in theyr olde age, so that all are partly borne to bee buried. For what man liueth and shall not see death, Psa. 89.48. Ecclstes. 3.1. saith the Prophet? The Preacher also telleth vs, that the ages of this life, are as the seasons of the yeere, for there must be a time to sow in, and a time to grow in, and then commeth haruest the time to mow in: But in certaine climates of the world, the corne is sooner reaped, because it is sooner ripe.

And so betwixt sooner and later, all of vs are gathered vp in the end, then seeing that death is a guest so well knowne to all men, and his message so vnauoydeable, that he still returneth, Corpus cum causa: Why should hee not bee as welcome to vs, as he is well knowne of vs,
and if it pleaseth God to translate thee before others, thy duety is to thanke him before others: if after others thinke that he giueth thee space, and pray him also to giue thee grace vnto repentance.

div.head: Text.
div.p:
THey that are acquainttd with Histories doe know the vnciuill dealing of sundry sauage nations with their dead: for some cast them out to be eaten of the wilde beastes: some hang them vp to be deuoured of the Foules of the ayre; others calling together their kindred, doe eate them as a banquet; some being more ciuill do imbalme them, & so preserue thē, & set thē a side in some secret place. But Christians doe moste duetifully and comely returne the earth his owne, after that God hath taken the diuine part of man. Act. 12.7. And as wee call buriall the last Christian duety that we owe eyther to other: So we esteeme the
denyall of Christian buriall, the foulest disgrace that can bee offered vs in this world, and to shew that men holde it in prize, we see many times that they whose life was very odious, haue their Funerals exceeding sumptuous. But wee may offend in this businesse of buriall twoo waies. Mat. 28.29. First in being ouer-curious (like the Pharises) in tricking of Sepulchers, and as they whose burial hath cost more after their death, then they were worth euen in their wealthiest state being aliue (if euery bird had receiued backe againe his owne Feather) so much more costly then comely is many a mans vanitie: Secondly we may offend in being too carelesse of comely buriall, as they who say: if I am dead, cast me on a dunghill, if you will. I say to such, that if they want Christian buriall, they want Christian duety, and God hath laide it as a curse vppon the vngodly heretofore, Ier. 22.19. as on Iehoakim by name, and diuerse other.

And the Psalmist bringeth in Ierusalem, thus lamenting that curse of God vpon them among the rest: Psa. 79.2. the dead bodies
of thy seruants, haue the enimies giuē to the beastes of the land: and the flesh of thy Saintes vnto the Foules of the ayre. I knowe it is no matter of saluation eyther to haue or to want Christian burial: Psa. 24.1. For the earth is the Lordes and all that therein is: and all that the world can doe is but to hurt the body, Luk. 12.4. and then they haue lost their sting.

So that although wee cannot haue christian burial: Yet tantundem est via ad caelos. Caeloque tegitur, qui non habet vrnā. But I would not haue any man to dispise buriall Diogines-like, who willed his friendes to laye him in the wide fieldes when he was dead: but when they replyed, that the beastes and Foules would feede on him, hee wished them to lay his staffe by him, in mocking manner. God himselfe hath a care of our departure, Psa. 11 • .15. for right deare in the sight of the Lord, is the death of his Saints, and we may not be carelesse of what God is most carefull. It hath good vse (out of doubt) that Joseph of Aramathia had a Toombe ready against his death: Lu. 23.53. that Abraham purchased a fielde properly for buriall: Gen. 23. and
that Iacob caused his eldest Sonne to sweare that he would carry him out of Egipt, Gen. 47.31. and bury him in Canaan, for these Scriptures (as the rest) are written for our immitation. And when Christians accompany their like to their long home, it hath a goodly grace: or (as Job saith) when wee deliuer a body to his Mother againe. But when an vngodly man is accompanied to his graue, it is like, as when a company of true men, followe the Cart that carrieth malefactors to Tiburne; or as when a flocke of Foules do passe by a dead Goshauke; or when the Dog-killer commeth by a dead Fox, he slippeth off his coate, but casteth away his Carkasse: who reioyceth not when wickednesse is going to the graue? The Executors are nimble fingred to tell his coyne, and share his bagges: the wormes bestirre them, for their feasting time commeth neere. The Deuill attendes diligently to cease vpon his soule in fee-simple; and therefore it followeth in the Text.

div.head: Text.

q.hi: And being in hell in torments.

div.p: Est locus hic partes vbi si via findit in ambas: The Scripture you see acknowledgeth but twoo waies: eyther men goe to heauens ioy with Lazarus, or els to tormentes with this damned Ghost, and that immediatly. So that if there bee a purgatory, the Pope hath purchased it of late, from some man, like himselfe, that he may make a gaine of it. As Simon Magus would haue bought that power of the holy Ghost by whole sale, Act. 8.18.19. that hee might haue solde it againe by retale.

And being in hell tormentes. The holy Ghost speaketh in the plurall number of the paines of the damned; As Moses saith, that God rained downe fire and brimstone from heauen vpon Sodom, Gen. 19.24. for God being a iust measurer, sendeth much punishment, vppon much sinne. This wretch was rich in sinne, Gen. 18. and therefore he hath a plurallity of punishment. For
shall not the Iudge of all the world doe according to right? Gen. 18. Yes, and therefore he that loueth to doe nothing but sinne, hath nothing but punishment: Psa. 99.16. they that loue not blessing, it is farre from them: and such as loue cursing, it hasteth to them: such as torment others heere, tormentes remayne for them heereafter.

When God threatneth destruction to the damned, he doth not say simply moriemini, Gen. 2.17. ye shall dye, but mortem moriemini, you shall dye the death, which the best translation turneth thus: moriendo moriemini, in dying ye shall dye: that is, you shall be euer in dying but neuer be dead: as the bushe that Moses sawe was burning, Exo. 3.2. but not consumed. Where it would bee great mercy to kill quicklie. There be in a great house, vessels of honor, and vessels of dishonor. The people are called vessell of being full or emptie. As the mighty vessels that Salomon made for the Temple was called a Sea, 1. Ki. 7.23. for the greatnes of the continent: but vessels of honor are so called, of being replenished with goodnes, and vessels of dishonor,
are such vassals as Pharo, Exo. 9.16. of whom God said for this cause, haue I kept thee: meaning partly that God might get him selfe honor on him, in his life, and at the last bring him to a dishonorable death. Grauia tendunt deorsum. Heauy things do presse downe, and it is not vnlike that in this sence the Hebrues (calling a rich man a heauy man) doe, Heb. 12.1. will Christians to cast away euery thing that presseth downe; meaning such thinges as hinder the good course of a Christian life, you see how hardly this burden is cast off by the young man, Luk. 18. who chose to keepe his present possession on earth, rather then to accept of that which the Lord promised in heauen. How like wealth is, to the bunch on the Cammels backe, keeping men from entring the straite gate, and much more from creeping through the needles eye: and you see howe low it pressed this man of great possessions, euen to the bottome of destruction.

The Deuill was of opinion that a man will giue all that hee hath, Iob. 2.4. to saue his life heere: How much more then should he do it to saue his soule. So that by the very
Deuils argument, a rich man had rather saue his life heere, then his soule should liue heereafter. I would to God they that desire to liue long, would endeuour to liue well: Gen. 47.9. for it is a good life that must bring a long life: Iacob said his daies were few and euill, not ill because they were few, but fewe because they are euill. And Paul in saying to the Corinthians; 1. Cor. 11.30 For this cause many are sicke, and weake among you, and many sleep; had relation to their prophane and vngodly life which then they led. But you see how dangerous it is for men to neglect times and occasions of performing the dueties of a godly life. There is also a note for all men to take heede what they doe, seeing it is iust with God, to send men one thing for another, if they doe one thing for an other,

The Diuines haue a Prouerb of Noas wine, Vinum non pepercit suo inuentori: which should make posterities prouident, in the like cases, and seeing it is euident that many men are as drunken with wealth, Gen. 9.21. as Noah was with wine: Schollers may also say of wealth, diuitiae
non miserentur sui Magistri. Noah was but deunken with his owne wine, but Diues was damned with his own wealth. Then a rich mans winding sheete, may couer his shape, but cannot hide his sin, and he may giue as many gownes as he can at his death, but the holy Ghost affoordeth his life led, neuer a cloake. Lord; who wold thinke that they which are greatest heere on earth, may misse soonest of the Kingdom in heauen? Here is no reason alleadged directly, why this party went to hell; but as Diuines doe, so all men may safely gather, that it was for abusing so manifolde blessings of the bountifull God. Gen. 40.19. So that as Joseph tolde Pharoes Baker his dreame, that the birds did eate the bread out off the basket which hee carried on his head, was a Prognostication, that foules should feede on his carkasse, when Pharoe had caused him to bee hanged. So the abusing of Gods blessings heere, is a figure of your partaking with Diues in his punishments as you haue done in his sinnes. You read in the Gospell, that the King passing sentence, vpon that vnworthy guest at the
feast which hee made at the marriage of his Sonne, Mat. 22.13. said take him, for he was none of that company, and therefore to be taken from among them, and binde him hand and feete, for those hands that neuer did good, must be bound to suffer euil: & those feete that walke not in any good way, must suffer the reward of going a stray. Binde hand & foote too, that he may haue no ease by turning or moouing, but lye still, and suffer still, and cast him, 2. Ki. 9.33. as Jezabel was cast out at a window. For God casteth off all care off such, as cast not their care on him, and they are right cast-awaies, into vtter darknesse, where hee must not remaine for three daies, (like Pharoe in that palpable mist of Egipt) but alwaies. Exo. 10.22. Psal. 16.11. Now in Gods presence is the fulnes of ioy, and at his right hand pleasure for euer: then, to bee depriued of his presence, is to be placed in sorrow, and to bee sent from his right hand of pleasure, is to bee possessed of endles paine. Psa 9.17. Thus shall the wicked be turned into hell, and all the people that forget God: Be admonished then (you rich men) by this burnt childe, to dread
the fire, Pro. 12.12. for the desire of the vngodly is a net of euils, saith the wise King, that is the desire of vngodly men is to ketch, for it is a net, and to ketch by euill, that is by euill meanes, yea it is a net to ketch himselfe, as he hath caught others. 1. Ki. 20.21. Num. 22.22. Ahab is caught by Elias; Balaam by the Angel; Pharoe in the Sea; Diues in hell: and euery one is ouertaken by his owne deuise, like Absalon with his owne hayre; Exo. 14. and Hammon with his owne gallowes; 2. Sam. 18.9. How is it then, that the warned are so few, seeing your warnings are so many? Est. 7.10. is it because ye haue not heard of an holie Ghost, Act. 19.2. or for that ye haue not receiued of his grace? Loe, you be the men that take not God for your strength, Psa. 52.7. but trust in the multitude of your riches.

You must all meete one day, Psa. 15.4. like Samsons Foxes, with fire-brands among you, for that is the place of them that knowe not God; Psa. 41.18. Ye Dolphins that play moste when a tempest is neerest; Psa. 16.30. Ye Philistines that are most merry when the house is ready to fall on you; Psa. 41.18. Ye sonnes of Leuiathan, that care no more for a sword shaken at you, then for a strawe: Luk. 12. Ye sensles
churles that feast most merrily, whē your soules must packe presently: Rom. 6.23. you forgette that the iudgementes of God are according to right. As he was Abrahams reward, Gen. 25. Deu. 10. so is hee euery sinners reuenger: many are your Eclipses here (you know) but heereafter your light shall be cleane put out, Iob. 18.6. and your selues turned into a smoke, like Sodom: you that haue caused whole spitle houses of pouerty, Gen. 19.28. you must suffer a hell of misery, where you must be deathes pray, Psa. 49.14. and hels perpetuall prisoners, where the plagues of God haue no end: Where that first borne of death, the hearts sicknes shall be seconded with the King of feare, Iob. 18.1 • .14 euen most dreadfull vglines: Two attendants which neuer leaue the damned in hell, where hee remaines as a tree plucked vp by the roote, Iob. 19.10. of whome there is no hope of any recouery. Iob. 3.1. If Job cursed his day, for a temporall affliction, that God sent him for a triall: O what will they doe, who in body and soule shall be taken with eternall and intollerable tormentes? God giue them grace to weigh this well, who in this life haue al pleasures, while Lazers are in all
paine. Who feast, while others fast: who laugh merrily, while the poore weepe heauily: who are cloathed like the Lillies, while others would bee glad of vile garmentes: who swim in the top of all prosperity, while Lazarus lyeth in the bottome of misery. Psa. 50.22. Consider this you that forget God, least he pluck you away sodainely, shewing you no mercy, as you haue helped none in their misery: if yee will not be Catechized by kinde instructiō, it followeth yt God will cut you short with a swift destruction. Therfore while you are young, liue well, that when you are olde, ye may dye well. If ye liue well heere, ye shall liue better heereafter: If ye liue ill now, ye shall liue worse an other time, for there is a better life, and there is a worse life: else what preheminence had the better aboue the worse, seeing both shall as surely dye, as they now liue. But as the voice said, Apo. 14.13. blessed are the dead, that dye in the Lord, for they rest from their labours: So cursed are they that dye, being as well of this world, as they are in this world, because they goe to their torments. 2. Kin. 2.11. Elias going
from the earth, was carried vp to heauen: Gen. 5, 24. and Diues going out of it, was turned into hell. God tooke away Henoch saith Moses, but the Deuill tooke away Diues saith our Sauiour Christ. And God knoweth how many of them, that weare silken garments heere, come to hels tormentes heereafter: and men haue iust cause, to weare blacke garmentes for them, that goe to euerlasting blackenes, not as though others mourning can any way help them, but because their owne misdemeanor, hath so irrecouerably hurt them.
